isis.stitle: International® DT 466E, DT 466, 530, 530E, and HT 530 Diesel Engines - Vibration Damper, Crankshaft, Main Bearings, Flywheel, and Crankcase - Clean, Inspect, and Test - Crankcase

note.para: Use a chemical bath or "hot tank" to clean crankcase during engine overhaul. Chemical bath removes all carbon material and mineral deposits that collect in cooling passages. If chemical bath is not available, use following cleaning procedure.

step1.para: Clean all old gasket material off surfaces of crankcase. Use scraper and sanding block.
Clean cylinder sleeve bores. Use nylon brush with soap and water.
Remove main oil gallery cup plug from rear of crankcase with hammer and chisel.
With cup plug removed, clean oil galleries and cross drilling. Use Main Oil Gallery Brush (ZTSE4389) with soap and water.
Blow out oil galleries and cross drilling with filtered compressed air.
Clean all threaded holes with an appropriate sized Critical Metric Taps (ZTSE4386) .
Clean mating surfaces of crankcase main oil gallery and cup plug.
Apply Loctite® to outside edge of main oil gallery cup plug.
Drive main oil gallery cup plug in crankcase with arbor, approximately 6 mm (.0236 in). Recess cup plug 3.2 mm (0.126 in).
Clean excess Loctite® off crankcase around cup plug before it hardens.

note.para: Threaded holes with damaged threads may be salvaged with use of a thread insert.
Do not resurface crankcase. Surface defects beyond those listed are not correctable. Replace crankcase.

step1.para:
Measure the crankcase deck for flatness. Use Bevelled Edge Straightedge (OEM1293)
and Feeler Gauge . Use flatness pattern. If 0.076 mm (0.003 in) feeler gauge can pass through, crankcase must be replaced.

Inspect both ends of cooling jet tubes while installed in crankcase. Verify flanged end under bearing saddle is intact and orifice end protruding from crankcase is not broken. Replace any damaged cooling jet tubes.
Shine light source under small orifice in tube end protruding in crankcase from insertion point in bearing saddle.
Look in large orifice of piston cooling jet. If light source is visible, tube is clear. If light source is not visible, tube is blocked. Clean tube to remove blockage.

caution.para: To avoid possible engine damage, do not use any metal wire or torch tip cleaner to force debris out of the jet. Internal orifice size is critical for correct power cylinder lubrication. Any distortion or increased orifice size caused by cleaning may damage engine.

note.para: Do not remove piston cooling jet tubes unless they are damaged or cannot pass visual inspection after cleaning.

step1.para: Blow debris out of piston cooling jet tube with filtered compressed air.
Shine light source under small orifice in tube end protruding in crankcase from insertion point in bearing saddle.
If compressed air alone will not dislodge blockage, replace piston cooling jet tube.
